#### B. ICU Benefit
If the Insured Person have been admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to an illness or Injury and treated with continuous life support devices for four (4) consecutive days or more in one Hospital admission, We will pay an additional 20% of the Benefit Limit up to a maximum of $25,000 per Insured Person. This benefit is payable once only. The payment of ICU Benefit will not reduce the Benefit Limit.
The admission to ICU must be deemed to be Medically Necessary by a Registered Medical Practitioner.
The following are specifically excluded:
i. Admission into High Dependency Unit or another alternative accommodation ward;
ii. Overseas medical treatment or hospital admission;
iii. Treatment provided under alternative medicine/therapy; and
iv. Any types of treatment or therapies that are experimental in nature, where approval from the Ministry of Health has not been obtained.
questions: What are the eligibility criteria for the ICU Benefit regarding the duration of ICU stay, type of medical support required, and the necessity of admission as determined by a Registered Medical Practitioner?
How does the ICU Benefit payment interact with the overall Benefit Limit, and what is the maximum amount payable under this benefit?
In what scenarios would admission to a High Dependency Unit or alternative accommodation ward be excluded from the ICU Benefit, and how does this exclusion affect claims?
How does the exclusion of overseas medical treatment or hospital admission impact the applicability of the ICU Benefit for insured persons receiving care outside their home country?
What types of treatments or therapies are excluded from the ICU Benefit when classified as alternative medicine or experimental, and what role does Ministry of Health approval play in this context?
Is the ICU Benefit payable multiple times for repeated ICU admissions within the same policy period, or is it limited to a single payment per insured person?
How does the policy define continuous life support devices for the purpose of qualifying for the ICU Benefit, and what documentation is required to prove this?
If an insured person is admitted to ICU for less than four consecutive days, how does this affect their eligibility for the ICU Benefit?
How does the ICU Benefit apply if the insured person is admitted to ICU due to injury versus illness, and are there any differences in coverage or exclusions?
What documentation or medical certification must be provided to demonstrate that ICU admission was medically necessary according to the policy terms?
How does the exclusion of experimental treatments without Ministry of Health approval interact with the general policy exclusions, and which takes precedence in claim assessment?
If an insured person receives ICU treatment involving both conventional and alternative therapies, how does the policy determine which treatments are covered under the ICU Benefit?
How does the ICU Benefit handle cases where the insured person is transferred from ICU to a High Dependency Unit within the same hospital admission?
What are the implications for the ICU Benefit if the insured personâ€™s ICU admission occurs overseas but subsequent treatment continues locally?
How does the policy address the timing of ICU admission in relation to the start of the hospital admission for the ICU Benefit to be payable?
In the event of a claim, how does the policy verify that the life support devices used were continuous and met the criteria for the ICU Benefit?
Are there any age restrictions or pre-existing condition considerations that affect eligibility for the ICU Benefit under this policy section?
How does the ICU Benefit coordinate with other sections of the policy that provide hospital or medical benefits, especially regarding overlapping claims?
What is the process for appealing a denied ICU Benefit claim based on the exclusions related to alternative accommodation wards or experimental treatments?
How does the ICU Benefit exclusion for overseas treatment interact with any general policy exclusions related to travel or location of treatment?
